DEBATE.TITLE: DEATHS OF FORMER SENATOR RONALD EDWARD McAULIFFE AND MR FRANK OLLEY, FORMER MEMBER OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the deaths of former Senator Ronald Edward McAuliffe and Mr Frank Olley, member of the House of Representatives for the division of Hume from 1972 to 1974.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 16 August 1988, of Ronald Edward McAuliffe, O.B.E., senator for the State of Queensland from 1971 to 1981, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Ron McAuliffe was born at Brisbane, Queensland on 25 July 1918 and educated at St Joseph's Christian Brothers College. He was an Australian Labor Party senator for the State of Queensland from 1971 until his retirement in 1981. During his time in the Senate, Ron McAuliffe undertook extensive work within the emerging committee system and showed particular interest in financial issues while a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, of which he was Chairman from 1973 to 1975. He was also a Temporary Chairman of Committees from March 1974 to April 1978. He will be remembered with gratitude by the party for his tireless service; he was Chairman of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party from May 1978 to June 1981. During the Second World War he was a member of the Australian Imperial Force, serving in the Middle East, New Guinea and at the siege of Tobruk.

Prior to entering parliament, Ron McAuliffe was a hotel proprietor, but one of his greatest loves was rugby league. He served for many years with the Australian and Queensland rugby leagues, being President of the Queensland Rugby League from 1970 and a member of the Australian Rugby League from 1973 to 1987 and its Deputy Chairman from 1980 to 1987. In the Parliament he contributed energetically to debates on sporting issues. In 1982 he was awarded the Order of the British Empire.

Ron McAuliffe will be remembered by a number of honourable senators. He was a warm, friendly and engaging personality. I will tell two stories, if I might, which I am sure he would not mind my telling. The first relates to my first week in this Parliament. In the Senate party room we all had mail boxes, which used to get cluttered with, how shall I put it, all classes of mail. I went in there very apprehensively to open my mail box, and Ron McAuliffe was outside his mail box, with an enormous dust bin. He was heaving everything out of the mail box into that dustbin. I was profoundly shocked by that, although I noticed that he was keeping the letters. I said that I was shocked and asked whether he read all those reports and things. He said that no, he did not. He said, `I will give you one other tip. Never answer letters. Send telegrams. It makes you look much more efficient'. I cannot say that I have entirely complied with his advice, but it was probably sound.

The second story relates to the rugby league final in 1975, which has now become part of the lore of Australian politics. The story goes that Ron, as President of the Queensland Rugby League, accompanied Gough Whitlam onto the ground to present the cup at the conclusion of the final. It is a matter of record now that the Whitlam Government was not overwhelmingly popular in 1975 and the crowd responded to the appearance of Gough Whitlam on the ground with enormous boos and by throwing beer cans and things of that kind. Gough turned to Ron McAuliffe and said, `McAuliffe, you'll have to work harder. I didn't realise that you were so unpopular'. Of course that story received popular currency only because Ron McAuliffe told it himself. As I have said, it has become part of the lore of this country's political history.

As I have said, Ron McAuliffe was a warm and friendly personality who endeared himself to many senators. I regard him, as I am sure all honourable senators do, as a respected member of this Senate; a loyal and tireless worker for his party. On behalf of the Government, I extend to members of his family our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

I suppose I share the same inward ambitions or thoughts of all the retiring senators who hope that, as a result of their service in and their contributions to this Parliament, they have made a small scratch on the mirror of time.

If Ron could hear me now I would say to him, `My friend, you made more than a scratch on the mirror of time. You were a soldier, a successful businessman, a highly regarded senator, a remarkable sports administrator and a dedicated family man'. The passing of a person so fondly remembered by countless people throughout Australia must leave a gap in his own family. To Ron's family, I extend my deepest sympathy for their loss. It may be of some small consolation to his family members that their grief is shared by so many others. As one of those others, I am proud to have been one of his colleagues and one of his friends. I, too, will miss him. I would like again to quote from his farewell speech when he said:

. . . there may be some merit in what the late Eddie Ward once said to a former Prime Minister, Sir Robert Menzies, when tributes were being made to a deceased comrade. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
acknowledges that:
(1) Australia was occupied by Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders who had settled for thousands of years before British settlement at Sydney Cove on 26 January 1788;
(2) Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders suffered dispossession and dispersal upon acquisition of their traditional lands by the British Crown; and
(3) Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders were denied full citizenship rights of the Commonwealth of Australia prior to the 1967 Referendum.
and affirms:
(4) the importance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture and heritage; and
(5) the entitlement of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders to self-management and self-determination subject to the Constitution and the laws of the Commonwealth of Australia;

and considers it desirable that the Commonwealth further promote reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander citizens providing recognition of their special place in the Commonwealth of Australia.

Mr President, in our bicentennial year, and at the outset of our first working day in this chamber, a motion such as this could hardly be more appropriate. Our new beginnings in this building allow us to focus with fresh minds on the great question-the great challenge-posed by our celebration of 200 years of European settlement: the nation's relationship with its Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander citizens. At the start of our bicentennial year, the Australian Heads of Churches issued a statement titled `Towards Reconciliation in Australian Society'. The idea for this resolution originated with that statement and the precise words of the resolution have been suggested by the churches. For this reason, and to prevent the injection of party politics into this motion, I believe it should be voted on without amendment from either side of the Senate.

The motion is in three parts. It begins by acknowledging as historical truths: firstly, the prior occupation and settlement of Australia by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people; secondly, the dispossession and dispersal they suffered after 1788; and, thirdly, the denial of full citizenship rights to them until 1967. Whatever one's political views or social theories those are undeniable facts of the Australian story.

It is not sufficient merely to acknowledge those truths without drawing out their implications-I believe, their inevitable implications. Accordingly, this motion goes on in its second part to affirm the importance of the Aboriginal culture and the entitlement of Aboriginal people to a substantial degree of self-management. The acknowledgment of these historical truths and the affirmation of these implications by this Parliament-and preferably a unanimous acknowledgment and affirmation-will go a long way towards their greater acceptance throughout the community.

It would still be inadequate to leave the issue at that point. We must add one logical step and draw one conclusion of ultimate significance. We must, if we are truly to fulfil our responsibilities as the elected representatives of the Australian people, express our utmost determination to promote reconciliation within our community. And we must do it today. We must, in the words of the third part of this motion, state the desirability of the Commonwealth further promoting reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander citizens, providing recognition of their special place in the Commonwealth of Australia.

In the informal discussions which have taken place among members concerning this motion, the view has sometimes been put that such a motion is purely symbolic and therefore of no importance or relevance to the Aboriginal and Islander people. I reject that view firmly. So do appropriate Opposition spokesmen such as Mr Chris Miles, who in April this year said:
I am open to symbolism and using the Parliament to bring about a resolution of past conflicts.

For many years governments of both political affiliations have endeavoured to provide what could be termed physical or technical solutions to the needs of the Aboriginal and Islander people. They have provided special assistance to help them in education, housing, employment, health and other fields. But we recognise that we must do more, for the education, housing, employment, and health standards of Aboriginal and Islander people still lag far behind those of the rest of the community. The Government is proud of its record in continuing and improving this flow of assistance. We will continue to do so, as the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will indicate tonight.

Yet we must also recognise that the true remedy does not lie purely in the allocation of resources, for if we provide budgetary assistance but not hope, not confidence, not effective consultation, not reconciliation, then that assistance will fail to lift Aboriginal and Islander people from their disadvantaged state. In the past, too many of those programs of assistance have been decided on by governments without the informed involvement of the people they were designed to assist. Even more fundamentally, those physical remedies for the physical needs of the Aboriginal people have not been accompanied by proper recognition of their cultural tradition or of their legitimate place in Australian society.

The proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission will be one major step in the direction of self-determination and self-management for the Aboriginal and Islander citizens of this nation. At the same time, the Government is committed to a real and lasting reconciliation, achieved through full consultation and honest negotiation, between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal citizens of this nation. This will be recognised by the preamble to the Commission legislation. It will be recognised by the compact or treaty which we are committed to negotiating with Aboriginal and Islander people. And, Mr President, it will be recognised by our support for this motion. Without this overall approach, without a proper settlement and proper recognition, there can be no real and lasting improvement for the Aboriginal and Islander people. That is why this motion is no mere symbolism or empty tokenism.

Mr President, this motion will not be the first formal recognition of the special position of the Aboriginal and Islander people. In 1967 the people of Australia voted overwhelmingly in a referendum initiated by the Liberal-Country Party Government to give the Commonwealth the right to make special laws for Aboriginal people. Significantly, this referendum had the support of all major political parties. In 1975 Senator Bonner's motion on `prior ownership' was debated by the Senate. That was Parliament's first formal step in setting the record straight and in pointing the way to reconciliation. Significantly again, it had bipartisan support.

Today Parliament must make a further statement. We must tell the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people that their feelings of dispossession generated by 200 years of non-Aboriginal settlement are recognised, that their culture and heritage are valued, and that through self-management their need for a more empowered place in the nation's life is affirmed. And more than that, this resolution will tell all Australians, Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal, that we are prepared to enter our third century of life together on this continent in a spirit of national reconciliation-not collective national guilt, not shame, but with proof of our capacity to recognise past wrongs and to build on that recognition a shared future of understanding and goodwill. What is required by government is the political will to follow through with these goals.
In a recent article about the proposed treaty, Dr H. C. Coombs said:
It's a politician's job to recognise when the will is there to do something: but they also have a responsibility to create that will.
And on the spurious claim that such a path to reconciliation would create division in the community, `Nugget' Coombs went on:

It's never divisive to correct injustice. The fact of injustice is divisive and will continue to be until we correct it and learn to live with it. People who benefit from injustice will oppose this, but you don't stop working for justice simply because people around you don't like it.

The Government is committed to correcting the injustices of the past. The political will is there, the support is there, as evidenced by this resolution from the churches. The aim is that we will all move forward together in a happier, more just and unified society. I commend the Australian Heads of Churches for their initiative in suggesting this important step on the road to reconciliation. In full recognition of the significance of this moment to Parliament and, not just to Parliament, but to all Australians, I now commend this motion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) has just commended this motion to us as a measure which might be used in this our bicentennial year to set us off on a better course than we have followed in the past with our Aboriginal Australians. The motion is one which sets out a series of statements of fact, contains a couple of affirmations and goes on to say that the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: considers it desirable that the Commonwealth further promote reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander citizens providing recognition of their special place in the Commonwealth of Australia.

It is certainly the wish of the Opposition to see that better course, to see the reconciliation and to see Aboriginal Australians with a better place in our community. Senator Button, in his speech, touched very lightly on the notoriously disadvantaged situation of Aboriginal Australians. It has been said over and over again in the Senate-although never before in this our new chamber-that by whatever social indicator one chooses to measure by, Aboriginals will generally be found to be in the worst situation. That has caused enormous concern to successive Australian governments, and since the year 1967 that concern has led to massive expenditure of public moneys in an attempt to remedy that disadvantage.

It is the view of the Opposition that the moving of this symbolic motion is not the most productive way to solve the problems that are undeniably suffered by our Aboriginal Australians. We would have thought that more constructive courses could be taken and, in particular, attention given, on the part of the Government and the Opposition, to the deficiencies in the approach to Aboriginal affairs which have been so evident over recent years.

But most of what is in this motion is unexceptionable. It may not be true that all of the statements are precise statements of historical fact. It is undoubtedly true that Australia was occupied by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders and that they have been here for thousands of years. It is not true, as the second paragraph of the motion implies, that all Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders were dispossessed. There remain in central Australia, in Arnhem Land and in the Torres Strait Islands some Aboriginal people whose occupation of their lands has continued from the time of settlement. I do not make that point to cavil. The reality is that, whilst the great bulk of the area of Australia was settled and there was a dispossession of those Aboriginals who occupied the land, there are substantial areas of land in Australia where that is not so. It is true that there was, for most of that period to 1967, a denial to Aboriginals of fundamental rights that were afforded to other people. For example, when I was a student in the late 1950s Aboriginal people did not enjoy the right to vote. A parliamentary inquiry at that time examined the issue and determined that they should have the same right as other Australians. But I suppose, in a technical sense, it is true that it was not until the 1967 referendum, which provided that Aboriginal Australians should be counted in the census, that there was full recognition of their place in this country.

There is no dispute from the Opposition about the importance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture and heritage. There is no dispute from the Opposition that Aboriginal Australians should be as free as other Australians to manage their lives and to lead the sorts of lives they wish. Sometimes those lives will be quite different from the lives of the average, run of the mill Australian suburbanite. No-one has ever objected to the fact that some Australians choose to separate themselves entirely from the community and go and live in monasteries under a vow of silence. We have not seen that as an objectionable or unAustralian thing to do. They have remained part of the fabric of Australia, although they have chosen to distance themselves from it.

But it is this second paragraph in this motion which gives rise to concern on the part of the Opposition. Later in my speech I will indicate why we will be seeking to move an amendment to that second affirmation with its reference to self-management and self-determination. The existing words can be used in a variety of ways. As I will be pointing out, they are used to describe concepts and approaches to the place of people in our society which would be utterly repugnant to most Australians. In particular, in so far as they give rise to the possibility of argument that there is, in the Australian nation, some separate nation of Aboriginal people who have some right to self-determination in a sense that I will explain-those words can be used in an international context-then we think the motion could be read in quite the wrong way. For that reason I will be moving an amendment to insert into the second paragraph words which subject the words `self-management' and `self-determination' to the qualifying words `in common with all other Australians'.

There is no argument about the continuing unhappy conditions of many Aboriginal people; there is no argument about the continuing need for assistance, and indeed generous assistance. But there is room for argument about what sort of assistance is effective. I think that there are few close observers of the Aboriginal scene in Australia today who believe that current approaches are effective across the board. Indeed, many people believe that the situation is worsening. I have said before in the Senate that, in my experience, in many parts of Australia the relationships between Aboriginal Australians and the rest of us have deteriorated significantly over recent years.

It is in that context that I raise the doubts which are felt by many on this side of the chamber about the use of symbols and the attachment of this Government in particular to symbolic approaches to this problem as against severely practical approaches to the problems of Aboriginal Australians. There are very great dangers in any approach which suggests to Aboriginal people that their problems can be externalised. There can be enormous difficulty in suggesting that there is some golden key solution, whether it be land rights, a treaty or a motion of this Parliament, when the reality is that the solution to most of the problems which face Aboriginal Australians requires not only government assistance but also an enormous amount of effort from Aboriginal people themselves. That might seem a conservative approach. That might seem an unfeeling and unsympathetic approach, but I would say in response--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is conservative.

—The senator from Tasmania interjects that it is a conservative approach. However, it struck me as ironic that when the present Premier of Western Australia, Mr Peter Dowding, who, like me, had a close association with the Aboriginal Legal Service in Western Australia-indeed, his association was closer; he worked for the Aboriginal Legal Service in the northern part of Western Australia-and who was involved, as Senator Cook was, in Labor Party promotion of Labor solutions to the problems of Aboriginals in Western Australia found himself confronted with the deep problems of his Aboriginal constituents and found the problems which are endemic in country towns in Western Australia, he made statements which reflect the same conservative view that I have just expressed. The other day, when he was concerned about what had been happening in Western Australia and attributed the difficulties to stirrers and outsiders, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I hope people recognise that the vast bulk of Aboriginal people make an important contribution to the community.
But it's time the vocal minority focused away from somebody else's solutions-money, handouts and asking what the Government is going to do.

That, I think, is a perfectly sensible response to the reality that it is not some overriding external solution to be sought; that is, in fact, a devotion to the particular and practical problems that are faced by people and a provision to them of an opportunity for them to help themselves. Any solution that pretends that that is not what it is all about is, in fact, a lie.

If one looks at the different symbols which have been used by the present Government over the years one sees a disturbing pattern that we do not wish to go on repeating. The reality is that when the Labor Party in opposition was looking for the answers to the then serious problems of Aboriginal people it came up with a solution of national land rights. In the Senate chamber down the hill, former Senator Susan Ryan spoke eloquently of the fact that the approach of the Government would be to operate through national land rights. She said that one of the first legislative acts of a Labor government would be to take the management of land out of the hands of the Queensland Government by passing her private member's Bill, which would be Labor legislation, to grant freehold title and not any other form of lease over the Aboriginal and Islander reserves in Queensland. She believed that that would resolve the situation. Those honourable senators opposite who campaigned on the Aboriginal issue in 1983 had these speakers notes; they were the notes of the Labor Party in 1983:
Labor will ensure that Aboriginal people in all States and Territories are granted land rights in line with the following principles:
Land will be granted as inalienable freehold

Labor will enact legislation to provide land rights to Queensland Aboriginal reserves immediately. Negotiations with the States to enact land rights legislation in line with the above principles will proceed.
where any state refuses to enact appropriate land rights legislation the Labor Government will use Commonwealth constitutional powers to achieve its objectives.

Why do I raise that now? I raise it now because, when I was dealing with the Aboriginal people in the late 1970s and early 1980s and we talked about their problems of alcohol abuse, of unemployment and of illness, they said to me, `The Labor Party has told us that we can solve these problems. They are going to give us our land'. What I am saying to you, Mr President, and to the Senate is that that was marvellously effective symbolism. Its greatest effect was to buy the votes of almost every Aboriginal in this country. This Government since 1983 has had untrammelled legislative power to enact that legislation, because the Australian Democrats are even greater supporters of that policy than are any Government senators opposite. That admission by Mr Holding, after another three or four years of misrepresentation to the Aboriginal people about that great symbol-the symbol of a promise of national land rights legislation-remained until 1986, when he dropped it and conceded that it was not a practical proposition. There was no difficulty about legislative competence; there was no difficulty about constitutional power or about having the numbers in the Senate. The fact is that the Labor Party in government had to face up to the legal, administrative and political realities of Australia and the realities that affect Aboriginal Australians.

We have here a piece of symbolism which is, I suggest, the fourth major piece of symbolism that we have seen from the Labor Party since the late 1970s: national land rights, the great symbol buried in 1986; the treaty, resurrected by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the Northern Territory and going where I do not know; the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission-and who knows what will happen to that-and now we have this proposed resolution. These matters are of vital importance to us. The reality of 1988 is that around Australia Aboriginal people are dying of despair in cells. That is a continuing process, week by week. I believe that this proposed resolution is not, by any stretch of the imagination, an adequate response to the reality that Aboriginal people face. Whilst it is, in most of its terms, unexceptionable in that it states, or almost states, the facts which are correct, it is in a number of respects a cop-out. Therefore, I believe that it is not something which should be paraded by the Minister at the table in quite the pleased way that he paraded it as he made his speech.

Let me turn to the important question of why we think the words in the proposed resolution are words of concern when they talk about the right of self-determination. That is an expression which is used in different ways in different circumstances. At international law the term can take either of two meanings. It can mean the sovereign equality of existing states and the right of a state to choose its own form of government without intervention. It can also mean the right of a specific territory, or people, to choose its own form of government, irrespective of the wishes of the rest of the state of which that territory is a part. It is that meaning that I ask the Senate to focus upon: the right of a specific territory, or people, to choose its own form of government, irrespective of the wishes of the rest of the state of which that territory is a part.

It is that second possibility-a possibility which is quite frequently adverted to by spokesmen for the Aboriginal people, including some Aboriginal people themselves-that makes it incumbent upon us to examine the use of those words in this proposed resolution. I am not raising some matter which has not been raised before. Before I sit down I will quote specifically from people who have argued that the Aboriginal people ought to have self-determination in that second determined sense. Let me say that while the Commonwealth Government is at present involved in discussions at the International Labour Organisation (ILO) about the rights of indigenous people, the fact is that this Government has raised concerns and objections about the idea that the expression `self-determination' might be used or interpreted:
. . . as requiring that national political institutions and legal systems be redesigned to reflect the character of indigenous populations.

That is a recent statement, a statement made within the last few months. The Australian Government made the point at the ILO session that I attended this year in Geneva that it does not want to hear that expression used in this way because of the dangers that do arise. Advice has been sought and I am told, according to an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, that that Department and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet have agreed that Australian Government delegates in international fora will not use the term `self-determination' to prevent its misinterpretation or its extension beyond Australian Government policy.

Mr Deputy President, that is the sole area that the Opposition raises as an objection of substance to this motion. This Government has cautioned against the use of the expression `self-determination' in an International Labour Organisation convention specifically relating to our indigenous people. We raise the same objection here. We raise the same concern and ask the Senate, therefore, to make a modest amendment to this motion simply to ensure that people of ill will cannot misuse it and that it cannot be used internationally to suggest that there is within Australia the seeds of a separate nation state. That is something which is alleged by some people, as I have said-I will go on to quote closer authority-in support of Aboriginal aspirations in this country. It is something which would not be in the interests of the Aboriginal people and certainly would be roundly dismissed by the great majority of Australians. The whole history of self-determination, of course, involves the proposition that people can self-determine themselves into a new nation state out of an existing political entity. I make that point because the motion already says that its right of self-determination is subject to the Constitution and the laws of the Commonwealth of Australia. Mr Deputy President, all peoples seeking self-determination in that international sense are within some existing body politic and subject to its constitution and its laws. Therefore, the international law on this subject would be utterly irrelevant if it applied only to people who are at large because there is not in the world people who are at large in that sense.

I turn to one other authority who has addressed people in Australia, a Professor Russel Barsh from the University of Washington in Seattle. He has made a number of statements within Australia about this issue and I quote from a paper of his called `Aboriginal rights, human rights and international law', Australian Aboriginal Studies, 1984, No. 2, page 4:

The relevant legal issue is not whether Aboriginal people were, or are now `sovereign', but whether they have a right to become independent through the exercise of self-determination. It is plain that Aboriginal people never executed any treaty surrendering their political rights, nor voted to incorporate themselves with Euro-Australians. Australian citizenship was conferred on them unilaterally. They cannot exercise the electoral franchise to protect themselves from injustice because they are a numerical minority. There is no real question of the territorial integrity of Australia because Australia can show no deed or treaty of title to the continent, and occupied much of it within living memory. The principles of self-determination and decolonisation appear applicable.

There is a visiting professor's view of our situation. What do we find said by spokesmen? I stress that these are minority spokesmen and I believe that most of the Aboriginal people have no interest in this argument. But the important thing is that it is used both within Australia and internationally. Paul Coe, who is well known to many honourable senators, is the Chairman of the National Aboriginal and Islander Legal Service Secretariat. He has argued that international law recognises the Aboriginal people's statehood and that the Commonwealth of Australia must recognise `the right to self-determination to the nation of Aboriginal people'. Shane Houston, the coordinator of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisations, has insisted that, despite colonisation of the continent, the Aboriginal people are a distinct people. He said:

We work to regain our independence, to remove the burden of oppression, to regain our right to self-determination, to carve out our rightful place from the monolithic block of repressive policies, personalities and practices which makes up the wider Australian society.

Despite oppression and attempts at indoctrination of colonialists schools, our inherent belief that the members of our communities collectively have the right to rule, that an individual's responsibility and right is to protect himself by guarding this collective right, remains.

One could go on. One could look at what was prepared by a body of Aboriginal people who got together to draw up a draft treaty-the National Coalition of Aboriginal Organisations; a peak body for various movements. One of its spokesmen, Mr Robert Riley, who was for a time on the staff of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs-I do not know whether he still is-talked about this as being philosophically spot on. The draft included a request for a land base of not less than 40 per cent of Australia providing for an Aboriginal state that is autonomous in government, development, culture and law.

All of that is part of the agenda which I and the Opposition believe is inherently destructive in terms of coming to grips with the very real issues which were raised by the Leader of the Government when moving this motion. Nobody could say that this Government has not been prepared to spend money; it has spent money as though it were going out of fashion. Over the last five years there have been vast increases in the rate of expenditure and, sadly, there is very little to show for it. The symbols have been produced and discarded. Today we have a motion which states some facts, with which we could not disagree, and expresses some aspirations which reflect statements of coalition policy going back over the years. We have worked hard to try to provide mechanisms which will provide a genuine basis for Aboriginal advancement and personal independence. We have had policies which have acknowledged the right of Aboriginal Australians to exercise that personal independence by forming outstations, by returning wholly or partly to a tribal life, or by fully incorporating themselves in the life of suburban Australia. As far as the policies of the Opposition are concerned, that is a matter of free choice and we have sought by a range of measures to promote the reality of choice.

We, like the Government, have made mistakes but I think one mistake we are not prepared to make is to hand a weapon to people who might use that weapon as a stick to beat a path towards the concept of two nations in this country. The very clear view of the Opposition is that that is a totally counterproductive way to go and the great bulk of Aboriginal people that I have met agree with me. Whilst I do not claim to have met the great bulk of Aboriginal people, I am sure that I have met as wide a sample as almost any honourable senator in this place. This motion does not reflect the idea of self-determination in its broader sense. It does not reflect their aspirations, whatever might be said by Mr Coe and others. For that reason I move:
Paragraph 5: After `self-determination' insert `in common with all other Australians'.
The relevant paragraph would then read:

the entitlement of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders to self-management and self-determination in common with all other Australians subject to the Constitution and the laws of the Commonwealth of Australia.

I believe that, with the insertion of that amendment, we could all, in good faith, support this motion and have the unanimous vote of this chamber. I would certainly welcome that, but I do not believe that we should wink our eyes or ignore the reality of the problem to which I have adverted on behalf of the Opposition. I do not believe that any of us should regard the passage of this motion as any more than a tiny contribution to the solution of the very considerable problems that are faced by Aboriginal Australians. In closing I again reflect on the sort of comments made by Premier Peter Dowding who, after long personal experience of dealing with his own Aboriginal constituents and working with them, has been moved to refer to the need for them to participate in the solutions which are to be found. I believe we sell the Aboriginal people of Australia short if we speak of these matters without remembering that absolutely essential element.

One of the reasons that self-management and self-determination are important is that they recognise the essential responsibility of Aboriginal people themselves, and I see that as being basic to any long term solution for many of the Aboriginal people of this country. I commend the amendment to the Senate and I commend the motion, provided it has that amendment, to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats strongly support this motion, recognising that it is long overdue but that, quite simply, it does not go far enough. We express the intention that legislation should follow to give legal recognition to prior Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander occupation and ownership of this country that we now call Australia. `Ownership' is not an appropriate word in the context of the indigenous culture. Land had and has a far deeper spiritual significance in that culture than something to be bought and sold and speculated against, as is the case in the European tradition.

SPEECH.PARA: The legal concept of terra nullis had no basis in fact. Its adoption as a legal principle provided an official justification and sanction for the dispossession which has now proceeded for 200 years. As I said, today's motion is long overdue. I should like to read into the record a short extract from the 1837 report of the Select Committee of the House of Commons (British Settlements) on Aboriginal Tribes. It reads:

The intercourse of Europeans . . . without any exception in favour of the subjects of Great Britain, has been . . . a source of many calamities to uncivilized nations. Too often, their territory has been usurped; their property seized; their numbers diminished; their character debased . . . European vices and diseases have been introduced . . . and they have been familiarised with the use of our most potent instruments for the subtle or the violent destruction of human life, viz, brandy and gunpowder.

It might be presumed that the native inhabitants of any land have an incontrovertible right to their own soil; a plain and sacred right, however, which seems not to have been understood. Europeans have entered their borders uninvited, and, when there, have not only acted as if they were undoubted lords of the soil, but have punished the natives as aggressors if they have evinced a disposition to live in their own country.

If they have been found upon their property, they have been treated as thieves and robbers. They are driven back into the interiors as if they were dogs or kangaroos . . . From very large tracts we have, it appears, succeeded in eradicating them; and though from some parts their ejection has not been so apparently violent as from others, it has been equally complete, through our taking possession of their hunting grounds, whereby we have despoiled them of the means of existence . . .

A new colony is about to be established in South Australia, and it deserves to be placed upon record, that Parliament, as lately as August 1834, passed an Act disposing of the lands of this country without once adverting to the native population!

That is an extract from a report written in 1837. We knew what we were doing in relation to the dispossession of the land of indigenous people, and yet we persist with that dispossession and cultural disenfranchisement of those indigenous people right up to the present day. In recent weeks an excellent and very moving account of the history of South Australia, as seen and told by the Aboriginal survivors of that holocaust, has appeared. The extract I have just quoted appears in the preface of that book, which is called Survival in Our Own Land. People with an interest in this matter or a concern for the holocaust which Europeans imposed on the indigenous people of this land should read this very moving account.

Last night the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his speech of welcome at the inaugural dinner in the Great Hall, reflected upon the perception legislators in this Parliament 200 years from now may have of the debates and legislation we are engaged in today. He was suggesting a linear view of history. At one level, the technical level, history is linear. The First Fleet took months to reach these shores from England and sailors travelled in sailing ships. Today, the same journey is completed in less than 24 hours in a fast and comfortable aeroplane.

But beside this history is another, which is of equal importance. It is the history of our humaneness, of the quality of our lives and relationships, one with another and with our environment. That history is by no means linear or progressive. As we have seen from the 1837 House of Commons report, there were men of greater humaneness and understanding than those who have succeeded them, who have populated this country, been elected to and served in its parliaments up to today. But let us not stop with 1837 or 1788; let us look at the humaneness of the indigenous people of this land, those who had populated this land for at least 40,000 years before white settlement. They were a gentle people who understood, far better than we do today, the close links between homo sapiens and the earth. That is the point I wish to stress in these remarks because I believe it lies at the core of this motion we are debating today.

The Australian Democrats express the hope that this motion will be followed by legislation giving legal force to some of the statements and concepts contained in the motion. We are therefore disappointed with some aspects of the wording, which we would like to have seen strengthened. We are also disappointed that neither the Minister nor the Prime Minister has given any consider- ation to improving the wording or making the meaning more explicit, being prepared to accept without amendment the motion as proposed by the Christian churches. It is my understanding that the motion before us is already a compromise, representing the most that was acceptable across a wide cross-section of political opinion. The motion was deliberately compromised to achieve endorsement by the Opposition parties, in the hope that it would achieve the support of all parties. The Opposition now wishes to weaken that motion still further by inserting the words which the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) has already moved by way of amendment. Those words seek further to perpetuate the denial of that special relationship between Aboriginal and Islander people, and the land.

The motion before us addresses several matters. Firstly, it states clearly and unequivocally that Australia was occupied for thousands of years before British settlement began on 26 January 1788-terra nullis confronted but not yet dispelled. The motion then states that Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders suffered dispossession of their land and dispersal, and were denied full citizenship rights until 27 May 1967-a period of almost 180 years. Dispersal is a very strange word in this context. If all the land was occupied, to where were all these people dispersed? The record is fairly clear: within less than 100 years some 600,000 people had been killed by a variety of means.

The motion then affirms the importance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture and heritage. But its importance to whom, and for what purpose? This is where the Australian Democrats would have liked to see the motion strengthened. As the motion stands, this could be read as a motherhood statement. Of course the culture of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders was and is important to them. That has not prevented Europeans from destroying the basis of that culture: the spiritual relationship with the land. Some academic Europeans, sociologists, anthropologists and others, have thought indigenous cultures to be important as items of study, but rather like museum specimens of long extinct fish. Is that what we mean by `importance'? The Australian Democrats would have liked to add five words to part (4) of the motion so that it read:
the value and importance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island culture and heritage to all Australians . . .

Related to this, and for the same reason, the final sentence, which affirms that `it is desirable that the Commonwealth further promote reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island citizens providing recognition of their special place in the Commonwealth of Australia', leaves unstated what their special place might be. Is it as a relict, peculiar and museum-like example of an irrelevant culture? We would like to have inserted the words `and contribution to' after `special place in' so that it would read: `their special place in and contribution to the Commonwealth of Australia'. This would clearly have indicated the unique and important contribution which the indigenous culture could make-indeed, should make-to a new and integrated Australian culture. This refers to a very different relationship which the Australian indigenous people have had with the land.

Two terms have dominated much of the media in recent weeks: `multiculturalism' and `one Australia'. Neither term has been clearly defined, but associated with the term `one Australia' has been the notion of supporting and defending `Australian values'. When I heard this expression I wondered about those values which both the Government and the Opposition hold up for emulation: more competitiveness for material gain; greed; a vision of a clawing, elbowing pyramid of bodies, with those who fight to the top seen as virtuous. Is this what we mean by `Australian values'? Competitiveness for exploitation of the environment is seen as one of the interpersonal competitive tools. Europeans have for several generations looked on land and the resources it carries as something to be traded, exploited and speculated against. It is clear to many of us, although not all in this chamber, that this attitude has rapidly produced an economy which is not sustainable. One of the cornerstones for change must be a more reverent and respectful attitude to land. Where do we find this different attitude? We find it right here in our midst. It has always been with us in the culture of our indigenous people.

On several previous occasions I have expressed in the Senate the hope that the bicentenary might be the beginning of a new Australian culture, a synthesis of those elements of Aboriginal and Islander culture with those innovative, creative and scientific traits which are unique to the European tradition. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have a unique and special contribution to make to a new and essential culture for continuing human and humane existence on this earth. We would like part (5) of the motion to read:
the value and importance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture and heritage to all Australians . . .
The last part of the motion would read:

and considers it desirable that the Commonwealth further promote reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander citizens providing recognition of their special place in and contribution to the Commonwealth of Australia.

This would clearly recognise that the emerging culture must include those elements of European and Aboriginal culture so that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture is not a relict, discrete, separate culture to be hived off and put somewhere else but one to be fully integrated, respected, revered and held in high esteem by all Australians from here on. It is not putting it too highly to suggest that unless we do that our survival is in jeopardy.

I turn to the amendment which has been moved by the Opposition. It relates to the last part of the motion. The Opposition seeks to add, after the word `self-determination', the words `in common with all other Australians'. We believe that the addition of those words would deny the recognition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture in the context that I have just been speaking of, in that the attitude to land by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders is quite different in kind from the attitude to land of all other Australians, both those who have come from England and those who have come more recently from other parts of Europe and Asia.

In recognition of that different and unique relationship with land, the terms `self-management' and `self-determination' should not be compromised by the addition of the words `in common with all other Australians'. That would simply give Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders rights which are in every respect no different from those of all other Australians, even with respect to the trading, ownership and use of land. As I have indicated, their attitude to land being different, they are entitled, we believe, to recognition of that different attitude. Therefore, the terms `self-management' and `self-determination' should not be qualified in the way proposed.

Senator Chaney has tried to argue that because all people are under a constitution and a law the words `subject to the Constitution and the laws of the Commonwealth of Australia' are in a sense irrelevant. He claims that those who are under such a constitution and such laws have nonetheless argued for separate statehood within the several states in which they occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is precisely the argument. Thank you; you have stated it correctly.

—That is the basis of the argument. Of course, if they succeed in achieving that object, then they are no longer under that constitution and under that law. But the wording before us says that Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders are entitled to `self-management and self-determination subject to the Constitution and the laws of the Commonwealth of Australia'. Clearly, while they remain under the Constitution and while they remain under those laws, those factors must apply to any claim which they make, and it seems to me that Senator Chaney's argument falls down on those grounds.

—Earlier on you stated the argument accurately. In any case where people seek self-determination they start from the point of being within some constitution and set of laws and at some point break out of that situation. That is the whole concept of self-determination.

—I am glad that Senator Chaney has explained that because again I do not think he really understands the wording which is before us. We who are not Aboriginals or Torres Strait Islanders are saying here that we are granting recognition and entitlement to self-determination and self-management subject to the Constitution and laws of Australia. What the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people might say in relation to their subjection to that law either before or after separate statehood seems to be quite irrelevant. They are at the moment under the Constitution and the laws, and we are granting them certain recognition subject to that Constitution and that law. I am afraid I cannot accept the argument that Senator Chaney puts.

SPEECH.PARA: The contrary argument is this: if one makes the entitlement of Aboriginals or Torres Strait Islanders to self-management and self-determination subject to the Constitution, et cetera, `in common with all other Australians', then one is doing no more than granting to those people those self-management and self-determination rights that are accepted by other Australians. Other Australians' attitude to land is quite different in kind from the attitude of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. It is that point which is being addressed in this particular part of the motion and it is that point which would be denied if the Opposition's amendment were accepted.
Indeed, if one looks at the Liberal-National Party policy statement, which I believe was adopted on 14 April 1987, one reads:
. . . in recognition of their special affinity with the land, Aboriginals must remain free to choose whether they wish to follow their traditional lifestyles or that of most other Australians.

It seems to me that in that statement the Opposition parties have recognised that in following their traditional lifestyles Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders have a different relationship with the land. I fail to see how those people can exercise that freedom to follow their traditional lifestyles if access to land is denied them or the model of land ownership which pervades the rest of Australia is imposed upon them.

The Democrats support this motion. We would like to see the motion go a great deal further. We would like to have seen it strengthened. We are disappointed the Government did not respond to our overtures to strengthen it with the few words I have mentioned. This motion is the beginning of a process which is long overdue. We hope that that process will be given legislative form in the not too distant future and that the recognition of prior Aboriginal occupation and ownership-I use the word `ownership' in parenthesis, as I indicated earlier-will be given legal form. More particularly, we hope the Aboriginal culture is given a more central place in the mainstream life of this country. I believe most fervently that unless that happens then the models which we are presently following are ones which simply cannot persist into the future. It would be a great pity if we did not accept the enormous gift which is being offered to us by recognition of that culture and that relevance to the changed attitude which we should have to the use of land, indeed to the use of planet earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), in moving this motion today, referred to its importance symbolically and as a bicentennial event. It is a pity that the Australian Labor Party (ALP) and the Government have chosen to pick up a notice of motion which they openly admitted was dictated to them by the churches. The members of this Parliament should be drafting the notices of motion that come before us. Whilst I am personally an active churchman and I have participated in this debate in church forums, I do not believe it is the place of Parliament to pick up and run with something according to the dictates of the churches of Australia. To a certain extent it is ironic that on this occasion the ALP is doing the churches' bidding.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw to Senator Button's attention that even within the church structures there has not been an easy or unanimous decision on this particular matter. I am a member of the Uniting Church in Australia and I am aware that very fierce debate has been carried on since February of this year in that church's house magazine, Church and Nation. In fact, I quote from an article in the February edition by the Reverend Bob Cook. He says:
When will leaders arise who will steer us in the direction of unity, integration, and justice for all citizens without discrimination?
When will we recognise that if we are to survive as a nation, if we are to avoid the evils of apartheid, we must stop seeing each other as black or white, but one nation, one people?
In the May edition of the same magazine, after a very fierce debate in letters to the editor, the issue was again taken up by the Reverend Bob Cook, who pointed out:

The latest fad is for churches to produce resolutions, and governments legislation, declaring that the Aborigines of a bygone age were the original `owners' of Australia-as though this were somehow relevant or significant for us who are alive today, even if it were true.

There is a degree of prophecy in the words of the Reverend Bob Cook which we ought to be mindful of today as we look at this issue in a political and community sense. It is interesting to see the emphasis that comes through in the platforms of the various political parties around Australia. The introductory remarks in the part of the Australian Labor Party's platform on Aborigines and Islanders read, in point 2:

With the coming of white people, traditional land was stolen, spiritual links shattered, the tribal economy broken, ritual life was disrupted and, in places, ceased. In many cases Aborigines and Islanders were murdered and tribes separated. Leadership and kinship structures and culture were often devastated and many Aborigines and Islanders became dependent on white people.

That is only a partial quotation, but it illustrates the degree of emotionalism that can often be injected into party platforms and discussions. The party of which I am a member and which endorses me for this place, the Northern Territory Country Liberal Party, has in its platform statement on the welfare of the individual a special section relating to Aboriginal people. This has significance because in the Northern Territory a high proportion of the community are Aboriginal. Let me quote from that platform document:

The Party recognises the fundamental right of Aboriginal People to choose whether they wish to retain their racial identity and traditional way of life or to adopt, partially or wholly, a European lifestyle. The Party endorses: encouragement of the principle of the preservation of Aboriginal history and culture; encouragement of participation by all Aboriginal Peoples in the mainstream of Territory society; development of Government Policies such that Aboriginals, without necessarily abandoning their racial identity, no longer need special treatment as a disadvantaged group within society.

In looking at the motion put before us today we need to be mindful of the recent initiatives of the Government. The two must be linked hand in hand, particularly if, as Senator Button says, they are to be seen as symbolic. What are the initiatives of the Government? We are all aware that the ALP is currently engaged in a massive reorganisation of the administration of Aboriginal affairs. It certainly has to be because over its seven years of government it has not been able, despite all of the massive government expenditure, to correct problems that have existed for a long time.

In December last year the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, tabled in the Parliament a document called Foundations for the Future, a policy statement to establish an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. It was an important discussion paper. It has been out in the community. It has certainly been controversial. It has already been amended a number of times by the Government. But the Government has not yet brought before the Parliament legislation arising from it-some seven or eight months later. I would rather seen the Government, as an act of symbolism in the bicentennial year, today, on Budget day, seven months after its initial discussion paper, have the courage to present legislation to enable debate properly to take place on how we should be assisting Aboriginals, where we should be assisting them and in what form.

The document Foundations for the Future referred to a number of issues which have not come about directly today in the motion before us. In the proposed preamble, which we are not able to see because the Government has not yet tabled it, there is very definite mention of the fact that Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders were the prior occupiers and original owners of this land, that as a consequence of these and subsequent deprivations the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples have become as a group the most disadvantaged people in Australia, and that there would need to be a means to rectify these consequences of past injustice.

In attachment B to Foundations for the Future, in relation to the proposed powers and functions to be in the legislation still to be tabled, powers and functions are alluded to with specific reference to compensation for dispossession and there is to be special recognition within the legal system of Aboriginal customary laws.

So land, legislation and compensation are important issues that should be addressed by the Parliament, but the Government is not bringing them forward even after seven or eight months of discussion and debate out in the community. Instead, it is still inviting us to concentrate on looking at the past, at where we have been and what the sins of the past were. Nobody is denying those sins. This motion is part of the psychology of the Labor Party; it raises expectations and precedents which can subsequently be tabled. If the preamble and attachment B to Foundations for the Future were to find their way into legislation, there is no denying that we would end up in the High Court of Australia with major new challenges and changes that are, in effect, constitutional. We are being asked to look at symbolism.

I take honourable senators back to June of this year when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) attended a major Aboriginal cultural function at Burunga. What came out of that? It was announced that the Labor Party Government was to go down the track of a special treaty with Aboriginal people. That has certainly been rejected by the coalition. It always has been. It is not timely to look at that area, and such a treaty would not meet the requirements of all concerned.

Why has the Government not had the courage to bring in the legislation if that is the track down which it wants to go? Instead, we are looking at a pious statement. The Government has a hidden agenda. The Government is hiding behind the guise of the churches. A political organisation within the left wing of the Labor Party and a number of radical Aboriginal organisations and groups around Australia are pushing particular wheelbarrows, looking for major legislative changes and constitutional developments.

Unfortunately, I have to raise again in this Parliament, as many people have done before me, the fact that we have never been able properly to define an Aboriginal. I quote from a major paper by a respected worker in Aboriginal communities, Pastor Paul Albrecht of Central Australia. A paper he recently gave stated:

The current Government definition of who is an Aboriginal Australian is a person descended from the original inhabitants of this land who chooses to identify as an Aborigine, and who is recognised as such by his group. According to this definition, aboriginality is a matter of race, since anyone who is in any way descended from the original inhabitants of this land can rightly and legally call himself an Aborigine. It is on the basis of this definition that people are eligible or ineligible for Government assistance provided specifically for Aboriginal Australians.

It is interesting to compare this definition with that used by the more traditional Aborigines. They define an Aborigine as one who knows his own Aboriginal traditions and lives by them. According to this definition, aboriginality is not a matter of race, but of culture.

This matter of Aboriginal traditional law and culture is probably one of the issues we should be addressing much more significantly. I have already referred to the Prime Minister's proposal for a treaty which he supposedly started to negotiate at Burunga. But let me point the bone at the Prime Minister specifically, because there was a major breach of sacred ceremonial Aboriginal law at Burunga. In the presentation of the bark and the petition to the Prime Minister, an Aboriginal, Galarrwuy Yunupingu, the Chairman of the Northern Land Council, seriously offended all of the traditional Aboriginal cultural leaders of northern Australia. He broke the law regarding ceremonial secrets, which are terribly important, in front of the Prime Minister, for political advantage. Mr Hawke and Mr Hand, therefore, have been innocent bystanders. They have complied with a very serious factor that is even reflected in the motion before us today which seeks to affirm the importance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture and heritage.

It is very hard for the old people to trust either the Government or, in particular, the Northern Land Council and Galarrwuy Yunupingu. The role of tribal elders for this cultural imperative has continually been depreciated. The Aboriginal law leaders are truthful and honourable men and women. For several months they have been calling on the Federal Government for funds to conduct a special meeting to investigate this religious infringement-this serious breach of sacred ceremony in front of the Prime Minister. Of course, the request has been put in some little backroom file. Mr Hand has had it for months but it has been sitting there. Culture is terribly important. Under the definition that Pastor Albrecht gives, I think it is even more important. Unfortunately, we often tend to confuse too easily the differences in the complex thing that we call Aboriginal life. Aboriginal society is very different. On the one hand it is very urbanised and, on the other, it is very traditional.

What has been happening to the role of the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation over the last few years under the Labor Government? The foundation is an independent Aboriginal organisation that looks very carefully at preserving Aboriginal tradition and law. Its charter is very wide in that area. But the Aboriginal Arts Board, comprising mainly urban Aboriginals from southern cities, does not see the need for the same emphasis in the funding authority. And neither does the Government. It has walked away. It has reduced funding and has insulted the traditional men and women who are tribal elders in Aboriginal society. So who really has the interests of Aborigines at heart? In the last few years this Government has more than halved the budget of the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation and has sought to manipulate it, through the Aboriginal Arts Board, which is now a very discredited statutory authority in its own right, because it has got into serious financial problems and been badly administered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense!

—The Minister should do some homework. There are funding priorities for Aboriginal culture and the whole area of Aborigines in Australia. The areas we need to address are the major ones of disadvantage, in health, education and welfare, and we need to encourage Aboriginal people, urbanised or tribalised, to have financial independence. Where do we go in the area of self-management and how does this proceed with any degree of security for the future? What does self-management mean to so many Aboriginal organisations around Australia, those that are vitally trying to do things in health, education and welfare? How do they recognise the special cultural significance, instead of trying to get a degree of cultural unity and transposing what are secret and sacred ceremonies of a tribal group into some dance mob hanging out of a theatre in Sydney? That is not preserving and properly protecting Aboriginal culture in our society. It is not recognising what the roles are.

SPEECH.PARA: The fundamental issues for Aborigines-whether they are to be dealt with through a new commission or by State governments-are in addressing the areas of disadvantage. My constituents who live in Aboriginal communities apply pressure to make sure that the administrative arrangements and the financial details are such that they can address those areas and can do so with a great deal of dignity, participating as normal members of our society. That is why Senator Chaney's amendment is so appropriate.

It is vitally important that there be the definition `in common with all other Australians'. I am not afraid of using those words. I can still recognise the differences in many ethnic groups in our community. I can still recognise the very importance of traditional Aboriginal culture. It has been there for centuries and it will be there for those who choose voluntarily to preserve those parts of it that are so terribly important. However, I find the Government's motives very underhand. I am suspicious. I can see hidden agendas and I can see the debate that has been going on. I can see the way in which Aboriginal leaders, such as Galarrwuy Yunupingu, have been played around with and turned into alternative politicians. I think that that is most unfortunate. We need to recognise that it is a function of government to address the disadvantaged. The preservation of cultural issues is a matter for the Aboriginal people. I commend Senator Chaney's amendment. If his amendment were to be included in the principal motion, that motion would be acceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Meeting in this new place, it is fitting that we acknowledge the fullness of human history in this land. This motion will stand as a statement of our commitment to national and individual reconciliation with the descendants of those who have suffered dispossession and dispersal in the wake of European and other settlement since 1788. Among those descendants I am proud to name one as my son-in-law. Honourable senators will recall that only one Aboriginal occupied a seat in either chamber of the old Parliament. As a senator and distinguished member of his race, former Senator Neville Bonner proposed the only other comparable motion in the Senate's history and that concerned Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. It was proposed in 1975 and was carried on the voices. Now, for the first time, a motion has been introduced in both Houses marking a new beginning in 1988 not only for the parliamentary representatives of the nation but also, hopefully, for those Australians who are the proud inheritors of a 40,000-year cultural heritage in this land.

SPEECH.PARA: In moving up the hill to this new meeting place, we represent a nation that has come of age when we are able to affirm, as this motion does, the value and importance of this cultural heritage, which can enrich the lives of all Australians. In voting for this motion in its entirety, I can assure the Senate and particularly the Opposition that I am voting to affirm the entitlements of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders to self-management and self-determination, subject to the Constitution and laws of the Commonwealth of Australia. I am not voting to espouse any separate philosophy of a nation within a nation; rather, I am voting to affirm the entitlement of our indigenous peoples to freely choose between their traditional lifestyles and that of other Australians. Although this choice is not, in the same sense, open to or made by other Australians, it is a necessary choice for indigenous people retaining a special affinity, as they do, with their land and trying to adapt across cultures to a harmonious co-existence with the new settlers and their descendants.

By participating in a new society, which has now been forged into a free and confident nation, Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders have attained their majority. They exercise full citizenship rights and now undertake duties that are common to all Australians. Twenty-one years after the 1967 referendum, I would like to recall the words of Mr Justice Brennan in the 1983 Commonwealth of Australia v. Tasmania case. I do not often cite this case as a precedent; nevertheless, I should like to quote the words of Mr Justice Brennan, because he went to the nub of this issue. At page 791, 46 Australian Law Reports 625, he stated:
The approval of the proposed law for the amendment-
to the Constitution-

was an affirmation of the will of the Australian people that the odious policies of oppression and neglect of Aboriginal citizens were to be at an end, and that the primary object of power is beneficial.
Again in that case, at page 816 Mr Justice Deane stated:
. . . it became increasingly clear that Australia, as a nation, must be diminished until acceptable laws be enacted to mitigate the effect of past barbarism . . .

This motion is an affirmation of the elected representatives of the Commonwealth that we are committed to a new start, to effecting reconciliation with those who have survived much trauma and who, having endured other trials, are reborn in the hope of full participation in the life of this nation. Miriam-Rose Ungunmerr-Baurman, an Aboriginal artist from Daly River in the Northern Territory, said:

The period of grieving must give way to a future of joy and inspiration. The period of despair must give way to a future of vital action. The period of grim endurance must turn into a period of vigorous growth.

Far from becoming a hollow utterance of political rhetoric, this motion can and should provide a point to a better future and a move from the old handout mentality to a mutual respect for the various perceptions of life in this land. There must be a recognition of the deep spirituality of the Aboriginal people. Policies which have materialism as their basis must be rejected. Policies which have an anti-family perspective as their basis must be rejected as being culturally inconsistent with the traditions of the Aboriginal people. I was able to visit the Northern Territory and speak to a number of Aboriginal people about the effect of X-rated videos being sold, hired and distributed in the Northern Territory. This trade was regarded by these people as a form of imperialism, an affront to their deep spirituality and to their commitment to family life. I will speak of that in another debate.

It is pleasing to note that this motion has been moved in response to a reasoned call for national reconciliation by the 14 leaders of the major Christian denominations in 1988. The Aboriginal Anglican Bishop Arthur Malcolm has stated his belief:

deep down, the majority of Aboriginal people long to hear at Government level an apology and admission that this was the Aboriginal people's land, that they are its forefathers and that white Australia is sorry that this was not recognised and acknowledged from the start. Until this happens, I don't see much headway coming-it has to be a two-way action.

The forecourt of this new Parliament House centres on the Aboriginal mosaic symbolising our land as a meeting place-the land inhabited by the first Australians for millenia before the first European footprint was implanted on it; the land which is now home for peoples from all over the world. As a free and confident nation, we are committed to living together, equal under the law, acknowledging our past and embracing our future. This motion is a significant and symbolic step. It is a significant attempt to contribute to that two-way action that has been referred to. As the heads of the churches said on 7 January this year:
We Australians . . . cannot be reconciled until we know each other, appreciate each other, our cultures, and our perspectives on life.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectively showeth:

2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack-itself the creation of three Christian crosses represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law.
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901 and each point depicting a State and the Territories of the Commonwealth.

4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to its form or to its acceptance as the sole Australian National Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ensure that the existing Australian National Flag remains sacrosanct from change and remains the sole national flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bolkus (from 1,402 citizens) and Coates (from 99 citizens).
