TALK.START.PARA: —I also seek leave to have the government response to parliamentary committee reports, tabled in the Senate by the President on 2 June 1988, incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
A. LEGISLATIVE AND GENERAL PURPOSE STANDING COMMITTEES
Legal and Constitutional Affairs
1. Freedom of Information Act 1982: Report on the Operation and Administration of the Freedom of Information Legislation.

The Committee's report was tabled on 15 December 1987 following two years of hearings and consideration by the Committee. The Government will have no difficulty in accepting the bulk of the Committee's recommendations. However all the recommendations must be carefully considered by relevant Ministers and agencies having regard to their likely cost and their impact on the public's rights of access to Government information. The Government expects to give a full response to the Committee's report during the Budget Sittings.
Science, Technology and the Environment
1. Examination of Annual Reports-Australian Libraries and Information Council.
The report contains a valuable review of the many inquiries which have been held since 1973 into the provision of information by libraries and other sources.

The report recommends the establishment of a representative Commonwealth body, which would advise Government on information policy issues, to complement the former Australian Libraries and Information Council (ALIC).
Since the Senate Standing Committee's report was tabled in 1985 there have been significant developments in the provision and co-ordination of information systems and services in Australia.

ALIC has been replaced by a new, higher profile and more ``pro-active'' body, the Australian Council of Library and Information Services (ACLIS). The objectives of ACLIS are, among other things, to foster the development and effective utilisation of Australian libraries, information resources and services and to provide advice to governments and public authorities about the development, improvement and co-ordination of these resources and services.
Although there are no formalised responsibilities within government for information policy, there is a growing awareness of the importance of information issues.
Ministers are urged to bear in mind the report when considering matters relating to information systems and services.

I endorse the findings of the Committee's report, but in respect of the principal recommendation, I do not favour the establishment of a new Commonwealth body to advise Government on information policy issues. I am satisfied that Ministers are aware of the importance of information in the economy and the Committee's report has been instrumental in raising this awareness. I would also suggest that existing bodies are capable of adequately addressing information issues.
B. SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE
Regulations and Ordinances
1. The Repeal and Re-enactment Device-82nd Report

The Committee's report arose from a referral to it by the Senate of a proposed amendment to section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 relating to commencement of regulations, which the Senate had omitted from the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1987. The Committee in its report recommended that the proposed amendment be accepted by the Senate subject to an amendment to overcome the Committee's concern about the possibility that the amendment could be used to impose retrospective liability. The Government agreed to the amendment recommended by the Committee. The revised amendment to section 48 of the Act was subsequently re-inserted in the Statute Law Bill and is now in force.

There were two other matters the subject of recommendation by the Committee in its report. The Committee recommended that legislation on these two matters should be on the statute book no later than the end of the 1988 Autumn Sittings.

The first was that the Acts Interpretation Act should be amended to prevent circumvention of the Senate's powers of disallowance by a delegated lawmaker using a sequence of repealing and re-enacting instruments. The Statutory Instruments (Tabling and Disallowance) Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, which is currently before the Parliament, addresses this issue.

In relation to the second matter the Committee recommended the provision of power of partial disallowance of regulations. This issue was the subject of correspondence between the Chairman of the Committee and the Attorney-General earlier this year. The Committee was advised by the Attorney-General that the Government does not support this recommendation. The Committee was informed that the Government believes that the present situation, in which objections by the Committee to the content of particular regulations are discussed with relevant Ministers and undertakings for amendment given in appropriate cases, works satisfactorily.
C. JOINT COMMITTEE
Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade
1. The Management of Australia's Defence
The Government's final response to the report will be presented to the Senate during the Budget Sittings.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that, following the resignation on 17 August of the Hon. Bill Hayden, Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) asked the Minister for Trade Negotiations, Mr Duffy, to be responsible for the Foreign Affairs and Trade portfolio until the new Minister is sworn in. This will take place on 2 September. Honourable senators will be aware that yesterday the Prime Minister announced the recommendations which he will be making to the Governor-General concerning changes within the Ministry. For the information of honourable senators, I now table a copy of that Press statement.

—My question is directed to the Minister designate for Foreign Affairs and Trade and Minister currently representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware of reports of the racially inspired massacre of an estimated 24,000 people in the small African nation of Burundi? Is the Minister aware of other such massacres occurring in the same country being carried out by the dominant minority tribe of the indigenous majority? What steps is the Government taking to register its concern and to bring about some concerted international response to this horrifying and tragic situation? I would remind the Minister that the original massacres of the early 1970s involved, as I understand it, the slaughter of virtually the whole educated class of the majority tribe. I ask the Minister: Does the Government support the imposition of sanctions, economic or otherwise, and does it propose any action or does it regard this as purely an internal matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been reports, horrifying in character, of a massacre of Hutus by the Burundian Army. The Army is formed almost exclusively of the Tutsi tribe, who dominate the Government of Burundi despite the fact that the Tutsis are a minority in the country, constituting only some 15 per cent of the population. The Hutus, by contrast, form some 84 per cent of the population. The recent reported events are not without precedent, as Senator Chaney said. Following an abortive Hutu-led coup in 1972, the Tutsis did engage in an appalling revenge massacre in which some 100,000 Hutus were killed.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is obviously very concerned about the recent reports. We condemn in the strongest possible terms such outrageous acts of violence. Obviously we will be giving consideration to an appropriate further policy response to that. I have to say that recent history shows that it is difficult for outside organisations, such as the Organisation of African Unity, to prevent such violations. Whether it is possible by some other form of bilateral or concerted international action to do something in response to the situation will obviously be the subject of further consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that answer and join with him in his strong expression of condemnation. My supplementary question concerns whether the Government will explore the international interest in some international action. I agree with him that the Organisation of African Unity has not in the past intervened in this case, but in light of the endless attention given to South Africa I ask the Minister to examine and I ask the Government to find out what international interest there is in taking strong action against what appears to be the most diabolical racist slaughter.
—I will take Senator Chaney's further question on notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the meltdown of the reactor at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in the Ukraine, in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, in 1987. What up to date information does the Government have on the overall impact of that serious nuclear accident? Does the Government now have current figures on numbers of human casualties, including numbers of evacuations from the area and any estimates of lost production as a result of that serious accident?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have some detailed information on this. I am not sure how much of it is new but, for the record, let me state as follows: the Chernobyl accident was the first power reactor accident in which fatalities were caused by radiation. According to the advice of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) of April this year, 31 members of the plant operating personnel and response teams were killed and more than 200 were hospitalised. Around 135,000 people living within a radius of 30 kilometres from the plant had to be evacuated. By the northern summer of 1987, 60,000 houses and other structures in 600 population centres had been decontaminated and residents of 16 villages in the outer part of the 30-kilometre zone were able to return to their homes. The IAEA has reported that much of the radioactive material released was carried away in the form of gases and dust particles by normal air currents. Radioactive materials were widely dispersed in this manner, with most remaining in the Soviet Union.

ANSWER.PARA: The economic costs of Chernobyl are difficult to measure. The Soviet leadership authorised reports, which appeared in January this year, suggesting that the total cost of the accident to the Soviet economy was some 8 billion roubles-that is, about $16 billion. It has been suggested that it may not be possible to measure the full economic effect of Chernobyl for another 30 years. The United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation-UNSCEAR, as it is called-has advised that no airborne activity from Chernobyl has been reported in the Southern Hemisphere.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the lame-duck and discarded Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, who is about to be replaced by Senator Ray, who in turn will become the fifth Labor Minister in this important policy area in as many years. Will the Minister confirm that the former Minister, Mr Young, issued an instruction to his consultant to increase the flow of business migrants from Europe and North America and to reduce the numbers being obtained from Asia? Is that instruction still in force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand that members of the Opposition are wanting to try to divert attention from their own problems in regard to their immigration policies. I was expecting this question to come from Senator Teague, who has adopted such a high profile and has taken such a strong stance in regard to the Opposition's immigration policies. Obviously, the Opposition has abandoned its bipartisan stance on immigration. Not only is this of great significance to all Australians; it is of great significance in terms of Australia's reputation overseas. I am sure that members of the Opposition would have seen the article this morning in the Sydney Morning Herald, under the heading `Anti-Australian Backlash Sweeps South East Asia'. I am not sure what implications that has in terms of our business migration program. I am aware also that the Ethnic Communities Council is very concerned about the Opposition policy and will be passing a resolution on Sunday endorsing the Federal Government's maintenance of a policy that is non-discriminatory.

ANSWER.PARA: To come to the text of the question, which I am in a position to answer, I am advised that the purpose of our business migration program is to attract to Australia people with capital and entrepreneurial skills who can contribute to the economic development of this country. We want the best people we can get and the widest possible range of skills and expertise. We cast the business migration net as widely as possible to attract the best candidates from all parts of the world and from all types of industry. Since there has been no upper limit on the number of business migrants, there can be no discrimination on the basis of race or country of birth; nor should there be. Any people who meet the criteria are accepted, regardless of where they come from. An applicant from Asia and an applicant from Europe will each receive the same consideration. We do not intend to compromise the economic integrity of the business migration program in any way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In doing so, I ask the Minister to answer the question that she was asked. I must repeat it because she has not dealt with it at all. My question to her was: Will the Minister confirm that the former Minister, Mr Young, issued an instruction to his consultant to increase the flow of business migrants from Europe and North America and to reduce the numbers from Asia? I ask: Was that instruction issued? Is that instruction still in force? I also ask, as a supplementary question, whether it is true, as was claimed on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program AM today by the consultant concerned, Mr Peter Cullen, that one reason for seeking more business migrants from non-Asian countries was that the existing program was quite `lopsided' because 75 per cent of business migrants were coming from Asia. I ask the Minister to answer that question specifically.
—I do not have anything else in my brief to add to my previous answer but I will take that section of Senator Short's question on notice-if he is still interested.

—My question, which is a repeat of the first question I asked in the Senate, is to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can the Minister advise the Senate of what is being done to alleviate the impossibly congested conditions at both Darwin and Alice Springs airports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to advise the Senate that the assiduous representations, over a substantial period, of Senator Collins and his Northern Territory colleague, Mr Snowdon, have borne fruit and a solution to the long-standing problem of terminal facilities not only at Darwin but also at Alice Springs is imminent. The Government has considered proposals put forward by both the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) and the Northern Territory Government to assume responsibility for the civil aviation facilities at those two airports. The Alice Springs Town Council has also applied to assume responsibility for the Alice airport. The Government has now taken a decision in principle that the facilities should transfer to the FAC. Detailed arrangements for the transfer are currently being negotiated. It is expected that the transfer will take place by the end of October this year.

ANSWER.PARA: The FAC has indicated that, upon the finalisation of mutually satisfactory financial arrangements for that transfer, it will immediately commence the planning of the redevelopment of civil aviation facilities at Darwin, including a new terminal. The terminal and associated works, which have a presently projected cost of $65m, will be targeted for completion within three years. The recently commenced $1.3m upgrading project at Alice Springs will be completed as planned. In addition, the Federal Airports Corporation has indicated that it will, as a matter of urgency, develop plans for further major development works at Alice Springs. Its submission to the Government in this respect has envisaged a projected cost of up to $20m for this development.

I say to Senator Collins that his has been a fine contribution on behalf of the people of the Northern Territory. He has done them proud and we will certainly have airport terminal facilities there that will do the country proud.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General aware of the findings of the Hon. Justice Marcus Einfeld, President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, in the case of sexual harassment brought by three complainants against Dr Atallah Sheiban under the Sex Discrimination Act 1984? Does the Minister agree with Justice Einfeld's failure to award damages and with the comments in his judgment that `Women with the normal experiences . . . know very well the various ways in which some men occasionally behave' and that `the public exposure of these complaints' and his findings were sufficient compensation? Given Justice Einfeld's own finding that each of the complainants was sexually harassed by the respondent, does the Minister consider that Justice Einfeld's comments and his failure to award damages represent a throwback to the days of `blame the victim' and shift the responsibility for sexual harassment from men onto women; are out of step with current law and thinking on sexual harassment; and are likely to deter women from seeking protection under the Sexual Discrimination Act? I ask the Minister to bear in mind the purpose of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the aims of the Sex Discrimination Act, when responding to my question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that in a recent sexual harassment case the President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission determined that the female complainants who came before him were sexually harassed by a male employer. But his additional finding was that they had suffered only temporary distress-I am merely relaying the determination he came to. The President, Mr Justice Einfeld, went on to comment that the public exposure of the complaints and his determination were sufficient relief to the complainants. He therefore refused to make a declaration in relation to damages. As I said, there was a determination that sexual harassment had occurred.

ANSWER.PARA: It should be noted, in case there is any attempt at generalisation, that the President has also sat on two other determinations, under the Sex Discrimination Act, involving allegations of sexual harassment. In determining these matters the President made declarations of amounts of $5,500 and $4,000 as damages for the complainants. That puts the activity of the President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, in determining complaints alleging sexual harassment, in a fuller context. That helps to answer the general misgivings and fears expressed by Senator Haines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of the devastating impact of the current Australian Customs Service dispute on customs agents, freight forwarders, importers and manufacturers? Is it a fact, for example, that at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport at Mascot last Thursday afternoon only one Customs officer was on duty and only one cashier was processing entries, and that only 10 per cent of entries at that airport were being processed in the normal manner and 90 per cent were being backlogged? Is it also a fact that last week senior Customs inspectors raided Mascot airport and removed documentation, and that the union has blackbanned the entries contained in those documents so that importers have little hope of obtaining those goods for weeks? Is it a fact that shipments have been backlogged for such long periods that local manufacturers requiring imported components have been forced to stand down employees? Would the Minister be prepared to instruct the Customs Service to accept blanket section 40aa letters for entry of goods or at least accept section 40aa letters on each individual shipment of goods during the dispute, because of the emergency situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I am quite aware of the dispute in the Customs Service, which has largely been generated by the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association in pursuit of particular staffing levels in the Public Service-not just in Customs. A number of measures have been taken by the Customs Service, in consultation with the Government, about the approach which should be adopted to this dispute. I am unable to agree with Senator Lewis's description of devastating impacts in their particularity. Of course, there has been an impact on agents, importers, manufacturers and so on. I would have grave difficulty in agreeing with the suggestion that there was only one Customs officer on duty at Mascot airport on a particular day last week.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, in relation to the last part of the question about whether the Government will instruct Customs to allow particular forms to be processed without Customs officers handling them in the normal way, I am not prepared to give an answer at this stage. There are a number of difficult problems in this dispute which have to be resolved with appropriate measures at particular times. I am certainly not prepared to give any undertaking about that because it may be that those sorts of actions are best undertaken in particular circumstances and in particular places, if it seems appropriate. There should be no blanket direction by me at this time in relation to that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of the Eighth Canberra Dental Seminar held last week at Fiji's Shangri-La International and followed this week with a post-seminar tour involving a three-day and four-night Blue Lagoon cruise and a two-day and three-night stay at Matamanoa Island? Are expenses incurred in travelling to such conferences tax deductible? Will the Government consider pro rata deductibility for the number of days spent in conference and the number of days spent in more pleasurable pursuits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some public-spirited citizen posted to me a few days ago-unfortunately, the person did not put a name on the envelope-a brochure soliciting enrolments for the Canberra Dental Seminar which, as Senator Schacht said, started in Fiji a few days ago. It is an event of six full days, in which a whole 8 1/2 hours is spent in discussing dental topics, 5 1/2 hours on how to dodge taxation, two full days `at leisure', three afternoons `at leisure', two evenings `at leisure', and four dinners or parties. In other words, on the face of that evidence, it is clearly not a business seminar or anything like that; it is a junket. It is asserted in this pamphlet that seminar expenses are tax deductible, and it gives the Australian Taxation Office reference number 4773709, Head Office, Canberra, Australian Capital Territory.

ANSWER.PARA: As I recall the law on this question, the Commissioner of Taxation makes an assessment according to how much of one of these junkets is business and how much is pleasure. I am afraid that I will probably not be able to tell Senator Schacht what the Commissioner has ruled. In my view, on the face of it, the Commissioner should not allow more than about 20 per cent of the expenses as a tax deduction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you leave it to the Commissioner to make up his mind?

—I have already said that the Commissioner makes the determination. I said that on the face of it not more than 20 per cent would be tax deductible. The dentists who participated have obviously picked up some of Mr Elliott's bad habits, but they have not done it in the grand style that Mr Elliott has. It was reported in the Sun of 11 August, under the heading `Big fish take to the high seas', that Mr Elliott, along with a couple of his mates, had taken a cruise in a 104-passenger yacht. I understand that that has probably been booked at some company's expense. I think the Taxation Commissioner perhaps ought to have a look at that as well. I will be proposing to the Treasurer that he might suggest that.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ADMINISTRATIVE AND CLERICAL OFFICERS ASSOCIATION: INDUSTRIAL ACTION

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. What action is the Government taking to ensure that the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association (ACOA) complies with the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's order to lift the bans it is imposing on the Australian Customs Service? Is it true that the Government is meeting with public sector unions to discuss the implementation of the 3 per cent wage increase this Thursday? Will the ACOA be present at that meeting? If so, is it appropriate that the Government should be discussing a pay rise with a union which is currently conducting an extremely damaging campaign of industrial action? Does the Government agree that this dispute is yet another demonstration of the need for effective compliance provisions in industrial legislation? Will the Government support the Opposition's amendment to the Industrial Relations Bill to insert effective compliance provisions, provisions that would undoubtedly have led to the speedy termination of this damaging campaign of industrial action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already been asked a question about the ACOA stoppage as it affects the Customs organisation. In answering that question I indicated that the Government had a very firm view about the nature of this dispute and would implement that firm view in a variety of situations. Consideration will certainly be given to the meeting relating to the implementation of the national wage decision later this week. The Government's attitude to the ACOA participation will be indicated prior to that meeting. Having said that, I do not want to pursue the particular details of the way in which the Government will deal with these matters.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chapman went on to ask me a number of other questions about what he called effective compliance provisions. He asked whether the Government would support an amendment, to be moved by the Opposition, to the industrial relations legislation in relation to effective compliance provisions. The answer to that question is no. I do not need to remind the honourable senator that those opposite experimented in government with what they called effective compliance provisions. The record of this Government in respect of industrial disputation varies between some 55 per cent less industrial disputation averaged over the work force and a 12 months period and something like 80 per cent. Indeed, the April figure for 1988 was some 83.5 per cent lower than the April average for any period in the last 20 years. One can go to various periods and make those comparisons. So the answer is that the Industrial Relations Bill will be debated at the appropriate time and the Government will indicate its attitude but will not be supporting the amendment. In relation to the Customs dispute, the Government will take such steps as are necessary when they arise.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AIR SERVICES: NEGOTIATIONS WITH THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

TALK.START.PARA: —Following Senator Collins's question to the Minister for Transport and Communications, I have another slow full toss for him: can the Minister advise the Senate of the outcome of the recently completed air services negotiations with the United States of America? In particular, can he advise whether there are any benefits flowing to Queensland as a result of these negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This does have a foreign policy dimension in it too, because the particular negotiations which were successfully concluded on the weekend bring to a close some two or more years of really quite tense and difficult relationships with the United States on aviation issues. The just concluded package represents a quite major step forward in our aviation relations. There have been some seven rounds of negotiations since May 1986 and another three this year since my exchanges in January with the United States Secretary of Transportation, James Burnley, which set the ground rules for the present discussions, which have been led with outstanding competence as usual, I might add, by my departmental Secretary, Peter Wilenski.

ANSWER.PARA: The package means expanded opportunities for the airlines of both countries and enhanced air services for the travelling public. The tourist industry in particular, not least that in Queensland for reasons which will become apparent in a moment, should benefit from the expanded network of services that will be possible under the newly granted rights. The situation is that the United States airlines will now be able for the first time to fly directly to Brisbane and Cairns and to one other Australian city of their choice and, in addition to that, to eight other Australian cities beyond these primary gateways. This will give the United States carriers access to virtually every international port in Australia and will mean both a rise in the overall number of overseas visitors and a greater spread of the benefits of inbound tourism across Australia.

There are, of course, reciprocal benefits for Qantas Airways Ltd-the agreement would not have been concluded without that-and they are extensive. Qantas, which before this agreement was concluded had rights to serve only Honolulu, Los Angeles, San Francisco and New York, now gains rights to an additional 11 United States cities of its choice, three of which can be served directly and eight via so-called primary gateways. Qantas also gains what are described as beyond rights to fly via the United States to a number of Canadian cities, which is an aspiration Qantas has long had, and has also restrictions removed over time on beyond rights to the United Kingdom and Europe. Moreover, Qantas's right to fly via New Zealand to all points to which it has rights in the United States has been confirmed, thus concluding the necessary corollary to the earlier successful negotiation with New Zealand.

Understandings reached on arrangements to allow for automatic capacity increases in line with traffic growth and airline performance will ensure that there are adequate flights to meet current and future demand while avoiding uneconomic excess capacity. The problem of finding an appropriate capacity formula which would be market driven, but at the same time not constituting complete capitulation to United States interests, has been one of the most difficult matters to resolve throughout this whole period of negotiations. The agreed package of additional traffic rights and capacity arrangements is, I think it fair to say, a major breakthrough which will greatly benefit the travelling public and the tourist industry. It does, as I said, bring to a close a period during which aviation has been a significant, though small, irritant in Australia-United States relationships.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Home Affairs. As a senator concerned for the country areas of New South Wales I ask whether the Minister is aware that in some parts of Australia-for example, the Riverina area of New South Wales-the Yes-No pamphlet prepared by the Australian Electoral Commission for the forthcoming referenda has not yet been delivered to some householders, notwithstanding the statutory requirement that the pamphlet be posted `not later than 14 days before the voting day of the referendum'. Does he not agree that, having regard to the importance and complexity of the proposed changes to our Constitution, this situation is a travesty of the rights of the individuals concerned to be informed in a timely manner about the changes so that they will be able to make an informed decision on 3 September?

—Section 11 of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 requires the Electoral Commissioner to have printed and posted to each person on the roll the Yes and No pamphlet. This should occur, as near as practicable, not later than 14 days before the voting day for the referendum. I stress `as near as practicable' because it was envisaged by the authors of the Act that maybe the 14-day limit was not absolutely practical, and the Act is couched in those terms. Every effort has been made to have those 10 million pamphlets sent to electors. The honourable senator points to problems in the Riverina. There is also an area in the eastern region of Melbourne where the 14-day provision has not been met. Every effort has been made. We are quite confident that by the end of this week all those pamphlets will go out. As the honourable senator says, it is the one way of getting the Yes and No cases across. I am sure all the people in the Riverina are walking out to their post boxes every day awaiting the arrival of this pamphlet, especially to read the rather pathetic No case.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ALLEGED DUMPING OF CEMENT AND CEMENT CLINKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce tell the Senate what the current status of the anti-dumping investigations into the alleged dumping of cement and cement clinkers is? Further, is the Minister of the opinion that the recent Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) report on the Australian cement industry undermines the industry's case in these inquiries?
—Say `yes' and sit down.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I must say that Senator Chaney gave me some gratuitous advice. I was asked whether I could inform the Senate of something, and he suggested that I stand up and say `yes' and sit down. The fact of the matter is that other honourable senators, including Senator Foreman, have a more intelligent interest than Senator Chaney in this topic. Therefore, I am not accepting that advice.

ANSWER.PARA: First of all, with respect to alleged dumping of cement clinker from Korea into Western Australia, a preliminary finding is due to be made and published by the Australian Customs Service before the end of this month. In the case of alleged dumping of cement from Japan into Victoria, the Customs Service has essentially completed its investigations with the Australian industry and has conducted normal value inquiries with the Japanese exporter and is continuing its inquiries with the importer. A preliminary finding will be made and published as soon as possible and not later than 11 November 1988.

Customs Service investigations will not be affected by the recent press reports of the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) study of the Australian industry as these investigations are conducted separately and independently. The BIE study was commissioned to assist the deliberations of the tripartite cement industry committee which was established earlier this year to examine the difficulties currently facing the industry in Australia and to report to the Government on what approach is necessary to restore the industry's competitiveness. Key findings of the BIE report were as follows:

That the Australian industry has significant competitive strengths in good quality raw materials, skilled work force, low energy costs, good technical support and backward integration from cement users.
But by overseas standards, significant sections of the industry have poor productivity levels due mainly to the use of outdated equipment, poor manning practices and limited competition.
The consequence has been that the Australian cement price is amongst the highest in the world.

While Press comment has tended to focus on the negative aspects of the industry, I was pleased to note that the BIE also found areas of the industry that are operating efficiently and competitively. These sectors should be able to compete effectively against any import competition. The committee is currently conducting meetings with interested parties and expects to report its findings to the Government at the end of September.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FOREST AND WILDERNESS AREAS IN TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I must say that I am pleased this position is still filled by Senator Richardson, who I have stated publicly is the best Minister for the environment we have ever had. But I would like to ask him some questions. The tall forests and wilderness areas of western Tasmania have been identified by both Commissioner Hitchcock of the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests and the Australian Heritage Commission as being of World Heritage value. Will this Government fulfil its obligations under the World Heritage Convention by nominating the area for World Heritage listing prior to 31 December this year? In view of the recent media reports quoting the Minister as approving mineral exploration, mining and hydro operations in the western Tasmanian wilderness, has the Government abandoned the Prime Minister's public guarantee that the forest areas and associated wild areas will be securely protected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The overriding obligation is to protect those very special parts of Australia, those parts that remain in almost pristine condition and those that are indeed in complete pristine condition. The Government, in taking the decision that it took a couple of weeks ago, has lived up to those obligations. The method of protection, of course, is up for negotiation. At the moment my colleague Senator Cook and I are conducting some negotiations with the Premier of Tasmania and one of his Ministers--
—He has turned out to be a decent guy.

—I am on his side as well, and he is on mine. We are seeking in those negotiations to secure protection for those areas. The way we will protect them, I hope, will be through an agreement with Tasmania which will involve joint Commonwealth and State legislation. That means that we can build upon the package Senator Cook negotiated with Mr Groom, which contained some very attractive features. As Senator Sanders would be well aware, anything which reduces waste in the industry and so places less pressure on the natural resource is in everyone's interest. If that can be achieved, obviously it is in everyone's interest.

ANSWER.PARA: The more important question Senator Sanders raised was about my approving mining, hydro projects, et cetera. In the discussions that we had with the Tasmanians the other day the Premier raised, in the first instance, the prospect of five hydro-electric schemes, all of which he said were located within an area commonly known in Tasmania as the hole in the doughnut. What I said was that even had we proceeded at this stage to nominate the whole of the area for World Heritage listing, hydro-electric schemes would not necessarily be banned. That is one thing the environment movement has yet to come to grips with. The World Heritage Convention does allow for what it terms acts of economic necessity. Therefore, if a necessity were demonstrated for a hydro dam, even if it were in a World Heritage area, it would be very difficult for the Commonwealth to reject any such application.

I did say to the Premier, and I hope that this is being put into effect this week, that officials from the Hydro-Electric Commission (HEC) ought to be in a position to demonstrate a necessity. I can recall the HEC saying that there was a necessity for the Franklin dam. After the Commonwealth rightly took the decision that it did in 1983, the HEC and the Tasmanian Government both acknowledged that that need never existed. In the case of the five proposals that were outlined to us last week-I think the word `outlined' is a fair indication; we were given no detail at all-we have not been shown any information which indicates that there is a real need for any of these proposals. It should also be stated that the Premier of Tasmania was at pains to stress that these proposals were not going to come on line until around the year 2010 anyway, so we were not looking at some project beginning tomorrow. As soon as we have received proper notification of the proposals I shall let Senator Sanders know.

I turn to the question of mining. Again, we were looking at mining in this hole in the doughnut area. At no stage during the discussions I had with the Tasmanian Premier and Minister was any mining or hydro work in the forest areas suggested. We were talking about the hole in the doughnut area. We were told about it being highly prospective. I am not sure, and I do not think there is enough information possessed by anyone anywhere in the country to indicate, how prospective the hole in the doughnut is. Part of the negotiations involve whether or not the Commonwealth might fund a geological survey of the area so that we can all find out what is there and what is not. Again, even in so far as World Heritage listing is concerned, if something is regarded as an economic necessity works can be allowed. As I am sure Senator Sanders is aware, I have given an indication to two mining operations in north Queensland that they can go ahead within a particular area because they will not take away the value that gave it its World Heritage status in the first place. If that sort of operation can be guaranteed in the hole in the doughnut or anywhere else, I am inclined to agree. But the honourable senator ought not fear that any of the forest areas that we are now obliged to protect will be mined or dammed or anything else, because they will not be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like to know whether the Government has agreed with the Gray Government to forgo any further World Heritage listing, as has been reported in the Press.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated to the Tasmanian Government that the Commonwealth would not proceed with any more World Heritage forest nominations in Tasmania without the concurrence of the Tasmanian Government. I think that is a pretty safe statement to make. A fair swag of Tasmania would be a World Heritage area if we listed this lot. There is a misunderstanding about the criteria that are necessary for World Heritage nomination. As far as forest areas go, I am quite convinced that, once one goes outside the areas of which we are now speaking, no area in Tasmania would justify World Heritage nomination anyway. The important thing to note is that the areas that we are nominating on this occasion are the important areas, the very best stands of the very tall trees. Once one goes outside those areas, I do not believe that there is a forest area in Tasmania that would justify World Heritage nomination. So I am not really giving up anything.

Apart from the weak and ineffective directives that the Minister issued to Telecom in June, which apparently do not affect those kinds of partnership deals, what steps will the Minister take to ensure that Telecom is not given a free ride to gain an undue competitive advantage to undermine competition and strengthen Telecom's monopoly stranglehold on the telecommunications industry? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond directly to the concern about the possible monopolisation practices being engaged in by Telecom by virtue of its association with Hewlett Packard. Any concern of that kind is met by the existing provisions of the Trade Practices Act which have full application to this situation. There is no substantial lessening of competition in terms of the Trade Practices Act. If any claim is made of the joint venture being actually or potentially anti-competitive so far as the position of other office automation equipment suppliers is concerned, the answer is that there is a clear obligation on Telecom, under section 46, I think, of the Trade Practices Act, to provide its monopoly services to its joint venture on exactly the same basis as it provides those services to the joint venture's competitors, with the sanction of the Act, of course, applying if it fails to do so. Quite apart from the operation of the guidelines which I announced recently, there is no question but that the very explicit sanction of the Trade Practices Act applies to this situation.

ANSWER.PARA: More generally, the Hewlett Packard deal is an example of exactly the sort of aggressive, effective, commercial behaviour that we want Telecom, surely to be engaging in. Back in 1985 Telecom publicly sought expressions of interest from office communication suppliers to join Telecom in a cooperative supply and merchandising venture. After a lengthy selection process, Telecom selected Hewlett Packard Australia as being best able to assist it to meet its customer needs. As a result, we have had the joint venture agreement to which Senator Messner referred. The joint venture company will acquire from HP Australia the business of distributing and servicing HP computer products that have commercial application. Hewlett Packard Australia will continue to distribute all other HP products and those other products are not intended to be marketed through the joint venture company.

It should be said, more generally, that in other countries links between computer suppliers and telecommunications carriers are becoming quite common due to the convergence of technologies that is at work in this area. Telecom's objective in entering the joint venture is essentially to meet a demand by major corporate customers for total information management solutions comprising telecommunications and computer integrated facilities. Telecom considers that it was simply not in a position to provide customers with such solutions. Telecom informs me that it is intended that the joint venture will be involved in research and development that may result in new products to both the Australian and export markets. It is of the view that HP's experience in development, manufacturing and international marketing will be very valuable to this activity. Telecom's commercial judgment was that, considering the benefits that would arise, a joint venture with Hewlett Packard was the best option available both to serve its customers and to enable Telecom to compete in the wider marketplace. There is certainly a recognition by Telecom that, under the reform process being implemented by the Government, the Australian Telecommunications Commission is completely accountable for decisions taken in terms of the joint venture company.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MURRAY-DARLING BASIN: SALINITY AND SOIL DEGRADATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources. In view of the serious problem of salinity and soil degradation in the Murray Valley, what steps is the Government taking to gain the cooperation of the States and community organisations in working towards its solution?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My first comment is to congratulate Senator Zakharov on pursuing the issue. Salinity is a major issue in this country. Over $600m a year is lost in rural production because of land degradation. Senator Zakharov has pursued this issue assiduously and that needs to be acknowledged. Senator Zakharov asked what action we were taking in the Murray-Darling Basin. If I am to pay tribute to Senator Zakharov I should also pay tribute to Senator Gareth Evans because, during his tenure in the resources and energy portfolio, he was instrumental in setting up the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council, which is a body on which the governments of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, along with the Commonwealth, sit. It is a ministerial council which recognises the fundamental truth that, when God designed the Murray-Darling Basin, he had no regard for the lines which cartographers later came along and drew on maps to delineate where the States were. In order to address the issue of salinity and land degradation in the Murray-Darling, there needed to be a cooperative arrangement between those three States and the Commonwealth. That was achieved in 1985.

ANSWER.PARA: The Murray-Darling Basin has 50 per cent of Australian crop land within its catchment. It has 30 to 40 per cent of total production from natural resource based industries that come out of the Murray-Darling Basin and it is an important and key agricultural area-if not the most important agricultural area in Australia.

As I have said, the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council, which oversees the Murray-Darling Basin Commission, was set up during the tenure of Senator Gareth Evans in the portfolio in 1985. It harmonises the interests of those three States and the Commonwealth. The last meeting of the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council was held in Adelaide earlier this month. The respective Ministers for land management, water and the environment from those three States and the Commonwealth were represented.

The Council adopted what I thought was a vital strategy-an anti-salinity and land degradation strategy. It decided to conduct, through that strategy, a series of programs aimed at reducing salinity in the Murray River by an amount of 20 per cent, measured at Morgan in South Australia. That is an achievable outcome. It is predicted that, as a strategy, it will save $110m a year in lost production from the Murray-Darling Basin itself. It will also provide the opportunity for over half a million hectares of high-value land in the basin to be protected. Those are the steps that the Commonwealth, together with those three States, is taking on what I regard as probably the most significant conservation issue in Australia-the issue of land degradation, in this case specified to the Murray-Darling Basin area.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April Senator Sanders asked me, again in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, a question without notice arising from correspondence relating to the relabelling of South African uranium to get around Finnish and Soviet embargoes. The correspondence that Senator Sanders's question related to was provided to him by Mr Jup Weber, a Greens member of the Luxembourg Parliament. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has forwarded me an answer to that question. It is in four parts and it is quite extensive, so I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

1. In my statement to the Parliament on 20 April I outlined the conditions under which the Australia/Euratom Agreement permits safeguards obligations to be exchanged within the jurisdiction of the European Communities. I would further note that an exchange of safeguards obligations within Europe can only be achieved with the approval of the EURATOM Safeguards Directorate (ESD) after application by the relevant organisation concerned;

2. It is certainly not a fact that exchanges of safeguards obligations in the European Communities are privatised and unregulated. The approval of the ESD is necessary before any obligation exchange can take place. The ESD is of course an official agency of the European Commission. It is the authority which regulates movements of, and exchanges of obligations on, nuclear material. The prior consent of Australia for exchanges of safeguards obligations within EURATOM is not required provided certain conditions, set out in my statement of 20 April, are adhered to;

3. Internal exchanges of safeguards obligations involving Australian obligated nuclear material do not alter the amount of nuclear material subject to Australian bilateral safeguards agreements. Neither do they affect the total amount of nuclear material which remains within the control of a bilateral partner country or group of countries.

International flag swaps (IFS) however have the same effect as a physical transfer of nuclear material from one safeguards jurisdiction to another. Under Australia's bilateral safeguards agreements no Australian obligated nuclear material can be re-transferred from a bilateral partner's safeguards jurisdiction without Australia's prior consent. Therefore any IFS involving Australian obligated nuclear material would also require Australia's prior consent.
For these reasons IFS are different from internal exchanges of safeguards obligations and require a different set of conditions.

4. Australian safeguards agreements do not ban exchanges of safeguards obligations on equivalent quantities of nuclear material within a jurisdiction. Their design and implementation have been successful in ensuring that obligated nuclear material subject to these agreements remains in exclusively peaceful non-explosive use.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Lewis proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The threat posed by the Hawke Government's referendum proposals to the role and independence of the Senate which protected the Australian people from the imposition of the I.D. Card, the Bill of Rights and the repeal of Section 45d of the Trade Practices Act.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose the following matter for discussion by the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: The threat posed by the Hawke Government's referendum proposals to the role and independence of the Senate which protected the Australian people from the imposition of the I.D. Card, the Bill of Rights and the repeal of Section 45d of the Trade Practices Act.

This is a most significant debate on the first full day of sittings of this House. The taxpayers of this country have just spent $1.1 billion or thereabouts on the construction of this magnificent edifice, so one could say that it has cost over half a billion dollars to bring us senators into this chamber. If the first referendum proposal to be put to the people on 3 September is carried by the Australian people, that money will have been totally wasted, because that proposal will gut this Senate. It will achieve all of those aims that the Australian Labor Party has been endeavouring to achieve for many years. It will make the Senate a mere shadow of the House of Representatives and an unnecessary expense for and burden on Australian taxpayers. Ultimately, in my view, it could, and probably will, result in some form of dictatorship of this country by a government which will not be bound to listen to a legislature such as the Senate is today, before this referendum proposal is put to the people.

If this referendum proposal were carried we would have all the falderal of a legislative chamber, as used to exist under the Westminster system, but we would have none of the power. The first question being put to the people in the referendum proposals on 3 September is an absolute crucial question for this Senate. It goes right to the heart of this Senate. The question appears to be simple but it is not simple; it is deceptive. The simple question being put to the people is: Do you approve of a law to provide for four-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament? That seems a simple question. In truth it is not a simple question; it is a most devious question because it contains within it the most serious threat this Senate has ever faced, and I am not referring to our terms of office. I am referring to the fact that the question contains within it, although it does not express it, these questions or these proposals: It abolishes the fixed term for senators--

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—It abolishes the rotation of senators--
—Hear, hear!

—And it includes the simultaneous election provision previously rejected by the Australian people in 1974, in 1977 and again in 1984. One will have gathered from the interjections of Senator Schacht when he has been saying `Hear, hear!' that he acknowledges what I am saying, that the first question contains within it those three proposals. It does not contain the deceptively simple question which the people of Australia will appear to be asked, but these questions about the abolition of fixed terms, the abolition of rotation of senators and the simultaneous election provision.

SPEECH.PARA: I alert supporters of the Australian Labor Party to the fact that that would enable a Liberal or National Party Prime Minister to call an election at any time the Prime Minister would wish and would enable that Prime Minister to take the Senate to an election. That will not just apply while honourable senators opposite have Mr Hawke as their Prime Minister or Mr Keating when they bring him in; it will apply for all time as a constitutional change and will enable people on our side to take advantage of having an election when it suits them. Honourable senators complained for many, many years that Mr Menzies used to call elections to his advantage and here they are putting it in the Constitution that a Prime Minister can have an election any time he likes and take out the Senate as well as the House of Representatives.

Until now the fixed term of the Senate has been the factor which has stopped Prime Ministers having elections whenever they wished to do so. It has been the fixed term of the Senate that has resulted in only four occasions when Prime Ministers have had the courage to take out the House of Representatives by itself and end up having a half Senate election by itself; only four times in 88 years. So clearly the fixed term of six years of the Senate has been a great detriment to Prime Ministers calling elections when it suits them, notwithstanding the Labor Party's criticisms of former Prime Minister Menzies and, I might say, of Mr Fraser in 1977.

Let me say to honourable senators opposite that it is they who are endeavouring to put this provision into the Constitution. The abolition of the Senate was in the Labor Party's platform for a long time and as late as 1980 Mr Hayden acknowledged that the Labor Party objective was eventually the abolition of the Senate. This would be the first peg in the abolition of the Senate. It has now been dropped from the platform but we do not forget what Senator Gareth Evans said before he came into the Senate. He said that the way to abolish the Senate or at least to muzzle it is to white-ant it from within. That is what this proposal is all about, muzzling the Senate. This would seriously weaken the ability of the Senate to resist objectionable measures like the ID card, the Bill of Rights and the repeal of section 45d of the Trade Practices Act.

Let me refer to section 45d of the Trade Practices Act. There was a very long, difficult and interesting debate in this chamber about the repeal of section 45d and after the Senate rejected the proposal of this Labor Government I can tell honourable senators that a senior Labor Minister gave thanks to our Lord, in my presence, for the Senate--

TALK.START.PARA: —Name him.

—I do not intend to name him. I treat what people say to me outside the chamber and in the corridors of this building as a matter of confidence. Let us look at the legislation in relation to the ID card.

—On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: I draw your attention to standing order 422. I ask you to draw the attention of the honourable senator opposite to it and request him to cease interjecting in this way.
—I do not consider the level of interjection to be unreasonable but if Senator Lewis considers it so I ask the honourable senator to stop interjecting.

—I want to refer to the legislation when the ID card was first introduced in 1986. Throughout 1986 the polls showed that the ID card was most favoured by the people of Australia. The support for an ID card during 1986 ranged between 65 per cent and 68 per cent whilst its disapproval ranged between 26 per cent and 29 per cent. So the Government thought it was on a winner with the ID card. The Liberal and National parties took a principled objection to the ID card and I might say that we were accused of being politically opportunistic. How we can be politically opportunistic when nearly 70 per cent of the people supported the proposal and we were saying that we opposed the proposal is absolutely beyond me. However, 70 per cent of the people in 1986 supported the ID card proposal. The Government introduced the legislation in November 1986 and the Senate rejected it.

SPEECH.PARA: If the first referendum proposal now being put to the Senate had been carried then and the Constitution had been changed as is proposed under this proposal, does anyone doubt that in December 1986 we would have had an election of both Houses of the Parliament on the ID card and that by 1987 the people of Australia would have had the burden of an ID card imposed upon them. The Government would have been returned as a resounding success because 70 per cent of the people in those days supported the ID card. Twelve months later, after an amazing debate in this Senate, we courageously rejected the ID card again to enable the Labor Government to have a double dissolution on the matter. Twelve months later the people of Australia finally realised, thanks to this chamber, all of the traps that were in the ID card and turned against it. Ultimately there were 43 hours of debate spread over nearly one year before a majority of the people came to understand the defects of the ID card proposal. I ask the Government whether that could ever happen if this proposal were carried. Could that ever happen again? Do honourable senators really think a government would allow a chamber to keep debating such a matter-such a difficult, crucial matter-for 12 months, until the people began to understand what the real issues were if this referendum proposal were carried? I know that there must be back bench senators in the Labor Party and the Government ranks who understand the points I am making and ultimately I will bet that in the secrecy of the ballot box they will vote no. Of course they will vote against this proposal.

Let me talk about the so-called Bill of Rights that was forced through the House of Representatives by a late night sitting ending at 3 o'clock in the morning. It was absolutely disgraceful. We had 36 hours of debate in the Senate and, 10 months after its introduction into the House of Representatives, the Government finally woke up to what it was on about with the Bill of Rights and withdrew it because the Government realised that the people were opposed to the proposal. That long debate in the Senate led to a groundswell of opposition to the handing over to non-elected judges of the power to rule on rights which have never been under threat in Australia and which, if they ever were, could be protected by laws passed by elected parliaments. Of course, that Bill was the idea of that zealot Senator Gareth Evans. He was the author of that Bill and only his enthusiasm kept it alive until intense scrutiny by this chamber ultimately persuaded the Government to cave in. That same Senator Gareth Evans wants to white-ant this chamber from within.

Let me talk about other matters where we have had great success. I just mention the Veterans' Entitlements Bill. We carried some 40 amendments to it and we debated it for some 13 1/2 hours. It went back to the House of Representatives and the House of Representatives accepted the amendments because they were good, worthwhile amendments which had resulted from sensible debate in this chamber. The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), which was brought into the Senate last November, was a terrible Bill. After we had applied ourselves to this Bill the Government took it away. It was deferred until the next session and it still has not come back into the chamber. Senator Button still has not brought back into the chamber the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). We do not know what the Government will do with that Bill but we know that at least we forced the Government to confer with industry on this question.

The Senate has repeatedly demonstrated why it is the legislative chamber that protects the people. That will always be the case because, under our system, the Government always has the majority in the lower House. That is how it gets to be the government. It wins enough seats in the lower House to become the government. Of course, it has the numbers in the lower House to carry its legislative program. Occasionally members of the Government backbench might have the guts or the courage to stand up to the Government and say, `That is wrong, Minister', or, `We do not like that'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very rarely.
—Only very rarely, as Senator Boswell says. Thanks to a fortuitous set of circumstances, when the legislation comes to this chamber it gets a thorough going over.
—Except when the Democrats gag it.

—I agree with Senator Puplick-except when the Australian Democrats gag it, as they decided to do towards the end of last session when they helped the Government gag through some 31 Bills in a week. Normally there is an opportunity for the Senate to analyse the legislation and give it the thorough going over that it needs.

SPEECH.PARA: What does the Government's first proposal mean? It does not mean that elections will be held only every four years. It is a maximum period of four years, not a fixed term of four years. It would enable the Prime Minister to call an election for both Houses-all of the Senate and all of the House of Representatives-at any time he wished to gain political advantage. Let me just give honourable senators an example. Journalists are too stupid to understand when we make this point. They say, `That would not happen; he would not do that'. Like hell he would not do that! Come October this year I can just imagine the Prime Minister saying, `The people have just passed this resolution. They have changed the Constitution. I take that as a mandate to enable me to have an election when I wish. I now wish to have an election in October 1988 and the issue I want to have the election on is tax file numbers'. We would then find ourselves, in October or November this year, in a three-week campaign over tax file numbers and, as things are at present, we would probably lose that election. The next thing that will happen is that the people of Australia will have a tax file number system.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we would not.

—Senator Chaney corrects me and says, `No, we would not'. Nevertheless, there is a chance that we would lose that election after three weeks debate. The Government would then be able to introduce tax file numbers because it would have the mandate, it would have the numbers and the Democrats would allow it to do so because they would say, `The Government has just fought an election on the matter'.

SPEECH.PARA: This proposal will not mean fewer elections. It will give the Prime Minister of the day much greater power over the legislative chamber-the Senate-than any past Prime Minister has ever had. It does not require the Government to serve out its term. It will not mean better government. It would radically change our parliamentary system. It would be different from anything we have known for the past 88 years. Our system would be different from that system which has served us so well until now. The change would cripple the Senate's independence. It would make it possible for the Government to control the Senate. We know that governments need courage from time to time but, believe me, parliaments also need courage from time to time. Governments certainly need courage to introduce their legislative programs but parliaments need courage to stand up to governments and say, `We will not pass this legislation in the form it is'. Parliamentary democracy is all about legislative chambers having the courage to stand up to the Government and say, `You are wrong. This legislation needs to be amended'. But if this proposal is carried there will be no Senate power to do that. As soon as the Senate tries to do that the Government will threaten it with an election and, if the Senate does not cave in, the Government will have an election on that issue. Of course, the Senate will not be able to win; the people will lose out; and the Prime Minister of the day will get an opportunity to serve a longer term.

This proposal will silence the independent voice of the smaller States. It will turn the Senate merely into a rubber stamp and, as I said in my opening remarks, it will make the spending of $500m on putting us in this chamber an absolute waste of taxpayers' money and result in needless future expense in keeping the Senate running. If the people of Australia support this proposal at the referendum we might as well do away with the Senate altogether. I say to the people of Australia, `Whatever you do about any issue, vote no to the first proposal being put by the Government'.

It paints a very artificial picture of the effect of referendum proposal No. 1, to be put to the people on 3 September. One great hurdle that Senator Lewis is unable to surmount is the fact that not one power, not one ability, not one legislative, deliberative or other function of this chamber is stripped away by this referendum proposal. SPEECH.PARA: The proposal simply says that in relation to the House of Representatives there shall be a four-year maximum term, and that on the same day that an election is held for the House of Representatives the Senate should go to the people also. What that does is to make this chamber, as I believe it ought to be, accountable to the people, at a maximum of every four years, and responsible for its actions. Former Senator Reg Withers has argued, as indeed my local Australian Labor Party branch in Sandy Bay has argued, that this will give to the Senate enhanced political clout, a greater role, because it will be able to claim that it has a mandate from the people concurrent with that of the Government in the Lower House. The fact is that holding an election on the same day for the Senate and the House of Representatives provides for a fair situation.
